STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 24, 2021
Jacquelyn Marry
Fostering Solutions
Suite A
131 S. Winter Street
Adrian, MI 49221
RE: License #: CB460360419
Fostering Solutions
Suite A
131 S. Winter Street
Adrian, MI 49221
Dear Ms. Marry:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 11/23/2021.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP was not successful and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of six foster care files did not have a service plan completed within 30 days of
case acceptance. The case was accepted 3/11/21; a service plan was completed
4/29/21.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of four adoption evaluations were not completed on time. One application dated
7/3/2019 had a home study completed on 3/12/21. The second file had an
application dated 3/12/20 with a home study completed on 2/19/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
1/10/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/6/20
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08E Foster care/juvenile justice action summary
Page 3
Within three business days of receipt of the PCA 320, Order
Placing Child After Release or Consent, by MDHHS, the
caseworker must document the following…
One of six foster care case files held a late closing DHHS-69. The case closed on
2/19/21, the form was completed on 3/16/21.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Page 2
An updated medical passport is provided to:
4

• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
 Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
 At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
 required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
 At or prior to each placement.
 Quarterly.
One of six foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports. A
medical passport was updated in May and November 2021. Another one should
have been completed in between those months.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11/30/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 12/16/20
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Five of six foster care files held contacts that were not entered within the required
timeframe.
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans
Page 10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker.
 Supervisor.
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart.
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
5

One of six foster care files was missing signatures on the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan. The 3/16/21 PATP was missing both parent’s signatures. The 6/14/21 PATP
was missing the father’s signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited as FOM 722-08C)
1/10/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/6/20.
11/30/20 RENEWAL, CAP approved 12/16/20.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Foster Home licensing renewal letter- the agency was advised to document in
the letter that an application has been enclosed.
 FTM 1105 forms- document specific names of attendees and how they
attended (in-person, phone, video conference, etc.)
 Ensure the 5307 is dated along with the signature before uploading into
MiSACWIS.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following area:
 Some Medical Passports did not reflect the most recent medical/dental exams
that were entered in MiSACWIS. As this is likely a MiSACWIS error the
agency was advised to contact the Helpdesk.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse or neglect during this licensing
period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. An investigation was initiated in July 2021 due to allegations the substitute
caregiver’s significant other would ‘swat’ an 8-year-old foster child. The investigation
was completed and found a violation of rule 9403(1d) regarding behavior
management. A CAP was approved on 9/21/2021. The CAP was completed and
closed on 11/10/2021. The investigation and CAP were reviewed and found to be in
compliance with licensing rules.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP, approved 12/16/2020, was a
result of the renewal evaluation dated 11/30/2020. The CAP addressed violations
regarding medical passports, PATPs, Family Team Meetings, and action summaries
(DHS-69). During this interim review, the agency had three repeat violations, which
require development of a new CAP. In the exit meeting the CA noted that two of the
violations, timely contact entry and completion of family assessments, continues to
be a struggle for the agency due to the strict timeframe requirements. While the
agency had some repeat violations, overall, the review showed a minimal number of
instances for each violation and significant compliance in several areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. The CA reported
the CAP from the 2020 renewal evaluation has been implemented. The CAP
included additional training and use of new tools for tracking and compliance. The
CA stated that staffing has remained steady over the past year. There are some
upcoming changes expected, but the CA expects the changes will positively impact
staff. The CA indicated that staff continue to balance their time between the office
and working remotely due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. However, it
continues to be challenging at times for staff to complete some face-to-face
meetings and obtaining signatures, due to illness and quarantine.
Interviews
Two staff were interviewed. The staff have been with the agency for over a year.
Both staff report the agency to be a very supportive environment. Both staff stated
their supervisors are knowledgeable and provide excellent supervision. Neither staff
had suggestions for improvements that could be made at the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
7

an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ _______________November 23, 2021__________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 23, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
